description: A heavy protective coat worn by firefighters, highly resistant to heat and flame.
A piece of clerical clothing, usually worn by Christian priests.
A fur coat with a couple small pockets.  Extremely warm.

variants.description: A classic status symbol for the rich and famous, this is a heavy and expensive coat made from luxuriously thick, soft, and rather short fur, with a color palette consisting of rich, deep brown.  One of the most popular types of fur coats produced and traded, this jacket is incredibly warm and comes with two modest pockets.

Fluffy and insulating, this expensive fur coat is composed of a small battalion's worth of snowy-white arctic fox pelts with silver tips.  A straight section forms the back and lower sweep, while triangularly cut furs are sown in an inverse pattern to form the rest of the jacket.

A straight-cut, classically stylish jacket crafted from soft and voluminous gray fox fur with a blue undercoat, this article of winter apparel comes kitted out with a tall collar and two modest pockets.

What was once a rugged piece of military clothing has metamorphosed into a fashion icon within this slim-cut and insulated jacket, with wide, cinchable sleeves and a broad collar.  Composed of sewn-together fox pelts and fastened with a zipper at the front, the inside of this jacket is lined with plush, reddish orange fur.

Luxuriously velvety and ridiculously extra, this warm, gray-hued coat is ribbed with patterns of black and white highlights.  Composed of a small army's worth of dead chinchilla pelts and naturally hypoallergenic, the world might be going to hell, but at least you'll look like a celebrity while enveloped within this dreamily soft, timelessly stylish coat.

Prey and predator are brought together within this luxurious fur coat, sewn from panels of velvety, snowy-white rabbit pelts and accentuated by a beige layer of fox fur trimming the collar and cuffs.  With a tapered waist and two side pockets, the jacket is both comfortable to wear and stylish.

The skins of what used to be several beavers have taken to the skies within the composition of this sleek-fitting flight jacket, or, rather, they would if the coat were in any way designed to be a practical piece of kit.  With a soft spread of brown fur lining the inside of this wide-necked overcoat and its exterior finished in a bold, glossy black color, it's safe to say that this garment belongs more within a ski chalet than the cockpit of a fighter craft.

Even more prized than regular mink jackets, this coat is exclusively composed of plush white fur with no markings or color in its undercoat.  Extremely warm and equipped with dual pockets, this expensive fashion statement would certainly turn some heads if anyone left alive could still care about aesthetics.

Possessing bell-bottom sleeves, a tapered waist, and a snowy-white fox fur trim around the collar, hem, and cuffs, this pure white fur coat dappled with striking spots would make any self-respecting aristocrat's heart swell in admiration.  Sown from sections of long and silky abdominal lynx fur and featuring two side pockets, the coat is extremely warm, elegant, and, thanks to the Cataclysm, completely free.

The favorite coat of old European royalty, this extravagant jacket of Russian sable is composed of stitched panels of cinnamon brown fur with a pale yellow undercoat and silver tips.  Possessing a tall collar and flaring hips that just might require you to walk sideways through narrower door frames, the coat is impractical, swelteringly warm, and incredibly stylish.

Before the Cataclysm, this fur coat would have likely been termed "ruggedly handsome," a nice way of saying that, while it's not as nice or as luxurious as other fur garments, its price was the same.  Regardless, the jacket's cinnamon brown fur and rust-red undercoat give it a pleasing aesthetic, while its long hairs are also both dense and durable.

This is a vintage tiger skin jacket smelling distinctly of mothballs, possessing an alternating blend of orange, white, and black striations ribbing its shaggy exterior, broadly flaring hips, and an interior lining of velvety chinchilla fur.  Illegal, before the Cataclysm, to either produce or sell, this coat is almost certainly one of the last of its kind and would make for a killer fashion statement, if you don't mind wearing the skin of a murdered, endangered animal, that is.

description: A garishly-colored faux fur coat with a couple small pockets.  Although not as warm as natural fur, it gives you some of that unique flair.
A long white coat with several large pockets.  Comes with a very nice pocket protector.
A vinyl coat with a hood and two very large pockets, meant to provide protection from rain.
An intricately sewn coat of treated and split intestines, prized for its light weight and waterproof qualities among the indigenous peoples of the arctic.
A padded coat with deep pockets and a hood.  Very warm.
A rugged full-length duster coat.  Has many pockets for storage.
A thick fur full-length duster.  Has many pockets for storage.
A thick faux fur duster, falling below your knees.  Has many pockets for storing things.
A thick leather full-length duster.  Has many pockets for storage.
A heavy, full-length wool coat.  Cumbersome, but warm and with deep pockets.
Plain black hakama for use in kendo and other martial arts.
A flowing, pleated garment which can be worn over a kimono.
An outer garment of absorbent, towel-like material traditionally worn to cover one's nakedness to and from the bath.  It makes you wish you had running water to bathe with.

//: Intended to be, and modeled off of, an M65 combat jacket.
//2: Considering that this is a stand-in for both original and reproduction M65 jackets, we're basing our overall dimensions and price on: https://www.helikon-tex.com/en_eur/ku-c65-dc-covert-m-65-jacket.html
description: A vintage article of military surplus with an adjustable waist drawstring, or at least a civilian reproduction of one â€” it's resplendent with a cotton liner, an integral hood tucked away in a zip-up pouch in the collar, and epaulettes upon the shoulders.
//3: The price of a surplus jacket would be much, much cheaper, but such is the compromise when you're simulating new and old in the same basket.
//4: The shell is made from a midweight NyCo blend wind resistant sateen, fully lined with a lightweight NyCo blend wind resistant poplin: https://omegamilitaria.com/blogs/reference-guides/the-ultimate-visual-buyers-guide-to-the-m65-field-jacket
//5: M65 jackets have a quilted liner of cotton that's generally removable. Considering that the player isn't able to extract the liner from this garment, we're assuming that the liner is in all the time, hence the quilted cotten material.

pocket_data.//: 6 inches tall, 4 inches wide, and 1.5 inches deep.
6 inches tall, 4 inches wide, and 1.5 inches deep.
7 inches tall, 3 inches wide, and 1 inch deep.
7 inches tall, 3 inches wide, and 1 inch deep.
4 inches tall, 2 inches wide, and 1 inch deep.

variants.//: Intended to be US M81 woodland camo.
variants.description: Tried and true, the US military's antiquated 4-tone woodland camouflage pattern covers this particular jacket: large, high-contrast patches of green, black, brown, and sand hues, all rather faded from years and ware.

variants.//: Intended to be US DCU camo.
variants.description: This jacket's brass zipper runs from collar to hem, a river of metallic brown knitting together the coat's arid-hued lapels, printed with a 3-tone mix of pale green, dark brown, and beige.  Looking at it, you wonder how many zombies are wandering about the gulf right now.

variants.//: Either original Vietnam M65 jackets, before M81 camo, or modern reproductions.
variants.description: Lacking much frills and fanfare, this simple, traditional jacket is dyed a solid shade of olive green with a brass zipper and buttons.
This particular garment has a base hue of dark tan, coated by myriad spots, blobs, and splotches of green, reddish brown, black, and grayish green to form a mottled, disruptive camouflage pattern.

This jacket's exterior shell is dyed a mix of blue and gray hues, with extra patches and disruptive striations, flipping between black and dark gray, covering the garment from collar to hem.  Chrome buttons, zips, and other fixtures glint from their home upon the coat.

variants.//: Intended to be US military UCP camo.
variants.description: The fabric of this particular jacket is coated in the pixelized camouflage pattern of the United States Army's former combat uniform, combining a sand-brown base with disruptive patterns of urban gray and sage green, as well as plastic zips and buttons.
Fitted with a brass main zip and corresponding buttons, this entire jacket forgoes frivolities and is, instead, dyed a solid shade of midnight black.

variants.//: Intended to be Swedish M90 camo. This is a civilian variant, and, yes, for some reason, out of all camo patterns, this exists: https://www.epicmilitaria.com/brandit-m65-giant-jacket-swedish-camo.html
variants.description: This particular jacket is sown from fabric dyed a base color of stoney gray with notes of brown, sprinkled through with large, splinter-like geometric shapes of green, gray, and hues of deep naval blue.

Dyed in a solid shade of rugged, earthen brown with a brass main zip and press-studs, this is a relatively handsome coat, so far as reproduction military equipment goes.  Obviously, the would-be soldier, prepper, and general wearer would most appreciate its utility in going undercover among the insurgent coyote population.

variants.//: Only used as a cosmetic variant for player professions that start with army jackets: currently the old veteran.
variants.description: Dyed in a 4-tone blend of worn green, black, sand, and brown hues, this particular overcoat had been your own issued service jacket when you'd still been in the forces, with your name stitched upon the right lapel and insignia pinned to the appropriate shoulder board.

description: A sleek blouse in a camouflage pattern with angled breast pockets and lots of loop velcro for affixing patches.  You might call it a jacket but it's really a blouse.  It has a pocket for your pen!
A double-breasted uniform to protect against the heat of the kitchen.

variants.description: It's colored white, the most common color for chef's jackets.
It's colored black, commonly used by chefs working in the night or who just want to look cool.
It's a royal blue color.
It's colored red.
It's colored pink, commonly used by women chefs or men who like pink.
It's colored yellow.
It has a camouflage pattern, perfect for chefs that want to hide in the wild.
It's colored white, and the front and back are printed with a giant skull between crossed kitchen knives.  Perfect for the apocalyptic chef.

description: A bright, cheaply made FEMA-issue windbreaker jacket with a hood.  One size, fits none.  Helps keep you unfrozen & visible for rescuers.
A jacket made from flannel, favored by outdoorsy types.
A jacket made from denim.

snippet_category.text: A jacket made from denim.  This one is haphazardly covered with patches featuring metal band logos.
A jacket made from denim, dyed black.
A denim jacket ornamented with yellow filament patterns.
An old denim jacket.  It has wears in several places and has lost its blue color, but its overall integrity is preserved.

description: A vest made from denim.

snippet_category.text: A vest made from denim.  This one is haphazardly covered with patches featuring metal band logos.
A vest made from denim, dyed black.
A stone washed blue vest made from denim.
A vest made from denim.  Its armholes have filament and torn fabric sticking out, as if someone just ripped the sleeves off.

description: This is a wrap over black jacket.  Commonly used by stealthy individuals hiding in the dark of the night.  It includes a pair of cotton gauntlets and a sash.
A jacket made from leather, offering more protection than your average cotton or denim jacket.

variants.description: This one is a dark black.
This one is a dark shade of brown.
This one has the symbol of a local biker gang on it.
This one is bright red.

description: A thin cotton jacket with a hood.  Good for brisk weather.
A light synthetic jacket with a hood.  Not very warm, but will keep out the rain.

variants.description: A distinctive deep blue windbreaker with "FBI" emblazoned on the left breast, on the sides of the sleeves, and across the back in large, yellow lettering.  It is only issued to FBI field agents, preventing misidentification.

description: A cotton varsity jacket, the type that the jocks in a highschool or a college would wear.

variants.description: This one is black except the white arms, and has no discerning emblem or writing.
This one has a dark green torso and white arms.  There is an emblem of a four-leaf clover with the writing "Clover High School" on the left arm and front right.
This one has a purple torso with white arms.  It has an angry looking old wizard on its back, holding its staff menacingly; below it writes "WIZARDS".
This one has a red torso and beige looking arms.  "'93" is embedded on both its arms, and there is a crest you can't recognize on its front right.
This one is completely black.  At least a dozen different patches are sewn on it.
This one has a yellow torso and black arms.  "New England University Robotics Team" in small letters is written on front left.
This one's torso is black and its arms are red.  It has an angry looking red bull ready to charge on its back.  Across the front writes "BULLS".
This one's torso is navy colored and has white arms.  You can see the logo of a well known brand in it.
This one is completely green save for the white stripes around the wrists and the hip.  It has a sprinting zombie clad in football gear on the back, above it writes "ZOMBIES".
This one has a pink torso and white arms.  Someone has sewn an equally pink heart on its front right.

description: Plain white judo gi.
Plain white karate gi.  Made from loose and flowing cotton.
A traditional, ankle-length Shinto robe with several layers and very wide sleeves.
A traditional, ankle-length Buddhist robe, stitched together from three pieces of traditional saffron dyed cloth.
Plain white keikogi for use in martial arts.
A traditional, ankle-length Japanese robe, wrapped around the body with a sash.
An easy-to-wear, breezy robe secured with a sash.  Essentially Japanese pajamas.  Great for summer nights.
A loose coat with wide sleeves that is worn unfastened over a kimono.  It is jet black with sparse, tasteful golden embroidery.
A white, knee-length cotton robe, traditionally worn by Jews on special occasions.
A thick and heavy leather jacket used most commonly by motorcyclists, equestrians and Australian vigilantes.

variants.description: It is emblazoned with the insignia of the local police force.
It is emblazoned with the bad-to-the-bone symbol of a biker gang.
This one is plain, lacking any particular decals.

description: A heavy wool coat, warm and with deep pockets.
A loose-fitting outer garment with sleeves and a mysterious amount of well-hidden pockets.
A white hooded ghost's robe characteristic of souls that haunt the living world.
A cheap ghost costume comprised of a white sheet with two eye holes cut out.  A simple hat is worn underneath to keep the sheet in place.
A black hooded grim reaper's robe with a face cover to hide the user's lack of facial skin.  It pairs nicely with a scythe.  Use it to remove the face cover and show yourself before your victims.

use_action.msg: The darkness surrounding your face lightens.

description: A black hooded grim reaper's robe with the face cover removed to show the user's lack of facial skin.  It pairs nicely with a scythe.  Use it to hide your lack of facial features.
//: 'Faceless' as in 'face cover'less and because, without the cover of darkness (A black face cover) a real grim reaper would really be faceless

use_action.msg: You shroud your face in darkness.

description: A mysterious and arcane-looking robe, signifying status in the wizarding world.  It has a hood and some pockets for your magical artifacts.
A traditional, double-layered Buddhist coat.  Used as an outer cloak for various occasions.
A red jacket, trimmed with white faux fur, commonly used by bearded men on Christmas.  Warm and has a couple of small pockets.
A short red jacket with white faux fur as trim, similar to a Santa jacket but sleeveless, for a more revealing look on Christmas.
An insulated, breathable hoodie made for alpine skiing.  Very warm, and with sizable pockets.

//: The general guideline for sleeveless dusters is the components, volume, weight, time to craft, and value are 15% lower (rounded down) than the original.  Making it from an original takes 50% the time.
description: A rugged full-length duster that leaves your arms unencumbered.  Has plenty of storage space due to its many pockets.

//: The general guideline for sleeveless dusters is the components, volume, weight, time to craft, and value are 15% lower (rounded down) than the original.  Making it from an original takes 50% the time.
description: A thick fur full-length duster without sleeves, leaving your arms unencumbered.  Has plenty of storage space due to its many pockets.
A thick, sleeveless faux fur duster, falling below your knees.  Has many pockets for storing things.

//: The general guideline for sleeveless dusters is the components, volume, weight, time to craft, and value are 15% lower (rounded down) than the original.  Making it from an original takes 50% the time.
description: A thick leather full-length duster without sleeves, leaving your arms unencumbered.  Has plenty of storage space due to its many pockets.

//: The general guideline for sleeveless trenchcoats is the components, volume, weight, time to craft, and value are 15% lower (rounded down) than the original.  Making it from an original takes 50% the time.
description: A thick canvas trenchcoat that leaves your arms unencumbered.  Has plenty of storage space due to its many pockets.

//: The general guideline for sleeveless trenchcoats is the components, volume, weight, time to craft, and value are 15% lower (rounded down) than the original.  Making it from an original takes 50% the time.
description: A thick fur trenchcoat without sleeves, leaving your arms unencumbered.  Has plenty of storage space due to its many pockets.
A thick faux fur trenchcoat without sleeves.  Has plenty of storage space, and looks pretty good.

//: The general guideline for sleeveless trenchcoats is the components, volume, weight, time to craft, and value are 15% lower (rounded down) than the original.  Making it from an original takes 50% the time.
description: A thick leather trenchcoat without sleeves, leaving your arms unencumbered.  Has plenty of storage space due to its many pockets.
A sleeveless cloth garment that covers the torso and legs.
A long, loose-fitting robe with wide sleeves.  A traditional Arab garment.
A thick canvas trenchcoat, lined with pockets.  Great for storage.
A thick fur trenchcoat, lined with pockets.  Great for storage.
A thick faux fur trenchcoat, lined with pockets.  Great for storage, and makes you the talk of the town.
A thick leather trenchcoat, lined with pockets.  Great for storage.
A simple garment long enough to cover down to the knees.
A poorly-made long tunic with a string tied around the waist to keep it all in place.
A full-body tuxedo.  Makes the apocalypse feel a little more classy.
An elegant waistcoat.  Ideal for those occasions when wearing only a shirt would be too casual and a suit would be overdoing it.
A hooded jacket with lots of pockets, thickly padded for warmth.  Favored by the military.
A thick black leather steampunk themed trenchcoat.  Unlike a regular trenchcoat, this one has no pockets.
A dark robbed cassock worn by plague doctors.
A dark piece of clerical clothing.  Typically worn by Christian nuns.

A hefty camouflage jacket rattling with a spade of zippers, press-studs, and attachment points, featuring a high mandarin collar, Velcro cuffs, plates for ID tags, and enough pockets to make your internal Militiaman weep for joy.
//2: Pocket dimensions are sourced from the reliable fountain of knowledge known as: I made a plausible enough guess after measuring the pockets of several other jackets that aren't this particular one to extrapolate them out into what they might feasibly be.

variants.description: Paying homage to the field-proven camouflage pattern of old US military uniforms, this huntsman's jacket is printed with a green, brown, and black woodland camouflage pattern.

Bright and dark green shades meet within the patterning of this tactical jacket, embellished by tones of earthen brown and other natural hues.  The trees of the Amazon will speak your native tongue as you stalk around, waging guerrilla warfare against the undead, with this jacket on.  It's just a shame that the rainforest is quite a walk away.

This adventurous-looking jacket would be at home on a safari to the Horn of Africa, dyed, as it is, in light greens, browns, and beige tones.  Then again, you suppose that every day's a safari now.  You're just not sure who's meant to be the hunter: you or the dead.

A staple companion of gamesmen whose trade lies within the watery recesses of wetlands, this water-resistant jacket is festooned with profile-disrupting lines and patterns printed in tan, gray, green, and black hues.

If you were traipsing off to the Sonoran desert, this pocket-laden jacket, with its sand-tan hues, streaks of beige and black, and ventilated interior, would have been your friend.  Now, all it is, is a reminder of a part of the world that may as well be the crust of Mars, for how remote and unreachable it is.
A comfortable overcoat for the summer-time mountaineer, hiker, or alpine hunter, this predominantly gray jacket is coated in jagged lines and geometric shapes of brown and white dye.

This particular pattern of jacket proved a relatively common sight among preppers during the end of days, printed in industrial colors â€” blacks, grays, and dirty whites â€” to offer better concealment within New England's man-made battle grounds.  Needless to say, a simple camo pattern proved of little help when push came to actual shove.

Resplendent in a wide assortment of blue and light gray tones, this versatile outerwear is the garment of choice for ocean-side activities, namely ocean activities with less fun sea-side paddling and more marine security and over-the-beach gunfights.

The fabric of this particular jacket is festooned with a camouflage pattern â€” a muddle of greens, light blues, browns, and gray â€” that would make it at home with any river-based huntsman or angler.  Its water-repellent construction ensures that one's possessions are protected from river spray.

Fit for utility in light snowfall and in the colder months, this jacket, while not as insulating as thicker winter overcoats, is resplendent with a mixed camo palette of snowy white, gray, and a hint of light brown.
Subtle and unassuming, save for the purely ludicrous number of pockets it's coated in, this hardy overgarment's outer shell is dyed a muted tone of gray verging into beige.
Modest and relatively plain, as far as tactical equipment goes, this particular jacket is dyed a solid shade of earthen brown.
The venerable shade of old military equipment, modern reproductions, and prepper camo-closets, this particular jacket is completely dyed a traditional shade of olive green.

Pitch-black, from its mandarin collar to its hems, this jacket is a coat for the aspiring nocturnal operator, tacticool edge lord, and those in the business to be afoot during the small hours of the night.
